</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(a) In 2016, UAL repurchased approximately 50&nbsp;million shares of UAL common stock for $2.6&nbsp;billion. In July 2016,
	UAL&#146;s Board of Directors authorized a $2&nbsp;billion share repurchase program to acquire UAL&#146;s common stock. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion remaining to purchase shares under its share
	repurchase program. UAL may repurchase shares through the open market, privately negotiated transactions, block trades or accelerated share repurchase transactions from time to time in accordance with applicable securities laws.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(b) The table does not include shares withheld from employees to satisfy certain tax obligations due upon the vesting of restricted stock units. The
	United Continental Holdings, Inc. 2008 Incentive Compensation Plan provides for the withholding of shares to satisfy tax obligations due upon the vesting of restricted stock units. However, this plan does not specify a maximum number of shares that
	may be withheld for this purpose. A total of 502 shares were withheld under this plan in the fourth quarter of 2016 at an average share price of $62.50. These shares of common stock withheld to satisfy tax withholding obligations may be deemed to be
	&#147;issuer purchases&#148; of shares that are required to be disclosed pursuant to this Item.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(c) Average price paid per share is calculated
	on a settlement basis and excludes commission.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	25
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(a) The number of
	revenue passengers measured by each flight segment flown.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(b) The number of scheduled miles flown by revenue passengers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(c) The number of seats available for passengers multiplied by the number of scheduled miles those seats are flown.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(d) RPM divided by ASM.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(e) The average
	passenger revenue received for each revenue passenger mile flown.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(f) Average stage length equals the average distance a flight travels
	weighted for size of aircraft.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(g) The average number of hours per day that an aircraft flown in revenue service is operated (from gate
	departure to gate arrival).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	27
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Table of Contents

</H5>
</EFX_FINANCIAL_DATA>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D300268D10K_HTM_TX300268_11">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;7.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United Continental Holdings,
	Inc. (together with its consolidated subsidiaries, &#147;UAL&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;) is a holding company and its principal, wholly-owned subsidiary is United Airlines, Inc. (together with its consolidated subsidiaries,
	&#147;United&#148;). As UAL consolidates United for financial statement purposes, disclosures that relate to activities of United also apply to UAL, unless otherwise noted. United&#146;s operating revenues and operating expenses comprise nearly 100%
	of UAL&#146;s revenues and operating expenses. In addition, United comprises approximately the entire balance of UAL&#146;s assets, liabilities and operating cash flows. When appropriate, UAL and United are named specifically for their individual
	contractual obligations and related disclosures and any significant differences between the operations and results of UAL and United are separately disclosed and explained. We sometimes use the words &#147;we,&#148; &#147;our,&#148; &#147;us,&#148;
	and the &#147;Company&#148; in this report for disclosures that relate to all of UAL and United.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	2016 Financial Highlights
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	2016 net income was $2.3&nbsp;billion, or $6.85 diluted earnings per share.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United&#146;s consolidated PRASM decreased 5.4% in 2016 compared to 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

</FONT>

	approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion remaining to purchase shares under its share repurchase program.

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	UAL ended the year with $5.8&nbsp;billion in unrestricted liquidity, which consisted of unrestricted cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and
	available capacity under the revolving credit facility of the Company&#146;s Credit Agreement.
</FONT>
</P>

	2016
	Operational Highlights
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">

<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Consolidated RPMs for 2016 increased 0.8% as compared to 2015, and consolidated ASMs increased 1.4% from the prior year, resulting in a consolidated
	load factor of 82.9% in 2016 versus 83.4% in 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For 2016 and 2015, the Company recorded a DOT
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-time
</FONT>
	arrival rate of 81.3% and 78.1%, respectively, and a
	system completion factor of 99.0% and 98.7%, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</FONT>
</TD>

</FONT>

</FONT>

	The Company took delivery of five new Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	787-9
</FONT>
	Dreamliners, eight new Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	737-900ERs,
</FONT>

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	737-800s,
</FONT>

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	777-300ERs
</FONT>
	and six used Airbus A319s. United exited from scheduled service
	four Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	757-200s,
</FONT>
	16 Embraer ERJ 145s and two Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	747-400s.
</FONT>
	The Company took delivery of the first Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	777-300ER
</FONT>
	in the
	Company&#146;s fleet, named the &#147;New Spirit of United,&#148; featuring the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	all-new
</FONT>
	United Polaris business class seat.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	The Company introduced new products to its industry-leading existing portfolio of products such as United Polaris service and announced Basic Economy
	fares which will expand its customers&#146; options.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	During 2016, the Company reached new agreements with every domestic unionized work group.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Outlook
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Set forth below
	is a discussion of the principal matters that we believe could impact our financial and operating performance and cause our results of operations in future periods to differ materially from our historical
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	28
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	operating results and/or from our anticipated results of operations described in the forward-looking statements in this report. See Part I, Item 1A., Risk Factors, of this report and the factors
	described under &#147;Forward-Looking Information&#148; below for additional discussion of these and other factors that could affect us.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The
	Company is committed to improving the efficiency and quality of all aspects of its business in 2017. In order to continue improving operational performance in 2017, our top focus will be on further improvements in completion factor, departure
	performance and baggage handling.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As outlined at our 2016 Investor Day presentation, the Company expects to drive significant incremental
	value by 2020 relative to 2015. United anticipates capturing this value through a variety of initiatives including a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-fleeting
</FONT>
	and upgauge program, additional customer choice through segmentation,
	improvements to the revenue management systems, ongoing sensible cost management, realizing our full network potential through improved schedule quality and enhancements to the MileagePlus program. In addition, the Company will continue to focus on
	improving reliability while increasing the efficiency of the operation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Economic Conditions.
</I>
</B>
	The economic outlook for the
	aviation industry in 2017 is characterized by moderate U.S. and global economic growth. In such conditions, we expect a moderate increase in the demand for air travel. Continuing economic uncertainty, along with the strengthening U.S. dollar, is
	providing uncertainty in key Asian, South American and European markets, and continued political and socioeconomic tensions may result in diminished demand for air travel.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Capacity.
</I>
</B>
	&nbsp;In 2017, the Company expects consolidated ASMs to grow between 1% and 2% year-over-year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Fuel.
</I>
</B>
	The Company&#146;s average aircraft fuel price per gallon including related taxes was $1.49 in 2016 as compared to $1.94 in 2015.&nbsp;Since 2014, the price of jet fuel has declined
	and remains volatile. Based on projected fuel consumption in 2017, a one dollar change in the price of a barrel of crude oil would change the Company&#146;s annual fuel expense by approximately $95&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Labor.
</I>
</B>
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United had approximately 80% of employees represented by unions. In 2016, United reached contract
	extensions with its pilots and dispatchers, amended collective bargaining agreements with its IAM represented employees, reached a five-year contract with the AFA covering all of its flight attendants and reached a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	six-year
</FONT>
	contract with the IBT covering its technicians and related employees. Additionally, the Company will be increasing pay for its pilots in order to align with a recently implemented contract of another
	airline. The costs associated with all these agreements is expected to add approximately $900&nbsp;million of costs for full-year 2017. The Company cannot predict the outcome of future negotiations with its unionized employee groups. Increases in
	the pay and benefits resulting from new collective bargaining agreements could have a material financial impact on the Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Results of
	Operations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In this section, we compare results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 with results of operations for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, and results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 with results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	29
</FONT>
</P>

<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Revenue

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The table below illustrates the year-over-year percentage change
	in the Company&#146;s operating revenues for the years ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The table below presents the Company&#146;s selected passenger revenue and selected operating data based on geographic
	region (regional flights consist primarily of domestic routes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD WIDTH="37%">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(a) See Part II,
	Item 6 of this report for the definition of these statistics.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Consolidated passenger revenue decreased $1.3&nbsp;billion, or 4.1%, in 2016 as
	compared to 2015. Consolidated PRASM decreased 5.4% in 2016 as compared to 2015. The decline in PRASM was driven by factors including a competitive domestic fare environment, lower surcharges, a strong U.S. dollar and reductions from energy-related
	corporate travel.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cargo revenue decreased $61&nbsp;million, or 6.5%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 due to lower freight yields and lower mail
	volumes year-over-year, partially offset by an increase in freight volumes. Freight yields were negatively impacted as air freighter competitors increased capacity in response to lower fuel prices. Another contributing factor to the year-over-year
	decrease was a U.S. West Coast port labor dispute that resulted in an increase in air freight results in the first quarter of 2015. The labor dispute was resolved during the first quarter of 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	30
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_14"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Expense
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The table below includes data related to the Company&#146;s operating expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Salaries and related costs increased $562&nbsp;million, or 5.8%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 primarily due to higher pay
	rates and benefit expenses driven by new and extended collective bargaining agreements, an increase in employee incentive expenses due to improvements in operational performance and a 2.2% increase in average full-time equivalent employees,
	partially offset by a reduction in profit sharing expense in 2016 as compared to 2015, a reduction in medical and dental costs and the results of certain costs savings initiatives in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in aircraft fuel expense was primarily attributable to decreased fuel prices and a reduction in fuel hedge losses, partially offset by the impact of a 1.4% increase in capacity. 2016 fuel
	expense includes the benefit of a $20&nbsp;million fuel tax refund. The table below presents the significant changes in aircraft fuel cost per gallon for the year ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Depreciation and amortization increased $158&nbsp;million, or 8.7%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 primarily due to additions
	of new aircraft, conversions of operating leases to capital leases, aircraft improvements, accelerated depreciation of certain assets related to several fleet types and increases in information technology assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Aircraft maintenance materials and outside repairs increased $98&nbsp;million, or 5.9%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 primarily due to a year-over-year
	increase in airframe maintenance visits as a result of the cyclical timing of these visits and volume-driven increases in component costs, partially offset by a reduction in costs due to the timing of maintenance on certain engines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Aircraft rent decreased $74&nbsp;million, or 9.8%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 primarily due to lease expirations, the purchase or capital lease
	conversion of several operating leased aircraft and lower lease renewal rates for certain aircraft.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	31
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="BORDER-TOP:3PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	See Note 16 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other operating expenses increased $343&nbsp;million, or 6.8%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 primarily due to increases in ground handling costs, food and
	technology costs associated with the Company&#146;s enhanced customer experience initiatives, rate-driven increases in hotel expenses for crews, increases in marketing expenses related to the 2016 Summer Olympics and volume-driven increases in cargo
	costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in interest expense of $55&nbsp;million, or 8.2%, in 2016 as compared to 2015 was primarily due to the
	prepayment of certain debt issuances in 2015 and declining balances of other debt, partially offset by interest expense on debt issued for the acquisition of new aircraft, the conversion of certain operating leases to capital leases and certain
	constructed airport assets accounted for as capital leases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Miscellaneous, net included losses of $80&nbsp;million from fuel
	derivatives not qualifying for hedge accounting. Foreign currency losses were approximately $43&nbsp;million and $129&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. Foreign currency results included $8&nbsp;million and $61&nbsp;million of foreign
	exchange losses for 2016 and 2015, respectively, related to the Company&#146;s cash holdings in Venezuela. Miscellaneous, net for 2015 also includes a $134&nbsp;million special charge related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unamortized
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	debt discounts for the early redemption of the 6% Notes due 2026 (the &#147;2026 Notes&#148;) and the 6% Notes due 2028 (the &#147;2028 Notes&#148;).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	32
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Revenue
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The table below illustrates the year-over-year percentage change
	in the Company&#146;s operating revenues for the years ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_18"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>

	region (regional flights consist primarily of domestic routes):

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;(a) See
	Part II, Item 6 of this report for the definition of these statistics.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Consolidated passenger revenue in 2015 decreased $977&nbsp;million, or
	2.9%, as compared to 2014 primarily due to a decrease in consolidated yield of 4.3% year-over-year. Yields were impacted by a competitive domestic fare environment, unfavorable foreign currency results due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar,
	international surcharge declines, travel reductions from corporate customers in the energy sector and increased industry capacity in certain regions. The decline in yields was partially offset by a 1.5% year-over-year increase in traffic.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	33
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>

	The table below includes data related to the Company&#146;s operating expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):

	&nbsp;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Salaries and related costs increased $778&nbsp;million, or 8.7%, in 2015 as compared to 2014 primarily due to a
	$463&nbsp;million increase in profit sharing costs as a result of improved profitability, higher pay rates driven by new collective bargaining agreements, an increase in medical and dental costs and an increase in pension expense resulting from
	changes in actuarial assumptions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in aircraft fuel expense was primarily attributable to decreased fuel prices partially offset
	by losses from fuel hedging activity and a 1.6% increase in capacity. The table below presents the significant changes in aircraft fuel cost per gallon for the year ended December&nbsp;31 (in millions, except percentage changes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Depreciation and amortization increased $140&nbsp;million, or 8.3%, in 2015 as compared to 2014 primarily due to additions
	in owned property and equipment, specifically related to new aircraft, information technology assets and several aircraft capital lease conversions from operating leases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Aircraft maintenance materials and outside repairs decreased $128&nbsp;million, or 7.2%, in 2015 as compared to 2014 primarily due to a year-over-year decrease in significant airframe maintenance visits
	as a result of the cyclical timing of these visits, improvements in the efficiency of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-house
</FONT>
	maintenance programs, a reduced volume of seat and landing gear maintenance and a reduction of flying hours under
	certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	power-by-the-hour
</FONT>
</FONT>
</FONT>
	engine maintenance agreements, partially offset by increases in expenses related to aircraft
	reliability projects and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Wi-Fi
</FONT>
	systems maintenance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Aircraft rent decreased $129&nbsp;million or 14.6%
	in 2015 as compared to 2014 primarily due to lease expirations, the purchase or capital lease conversion of several operating leased aircraft and lower lease renewal rates for certain aircraft.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	34
</FONT>
</P>

<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_23"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Nonoperating Income (Expense)
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table illustrates the year-over-year dollar and percentage changes in UAL&#146;s nonoperating income (expense) (in millions, except
	percentage changes):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="48%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in interest expense of $66&nbsp;million, or 9.0%, in 2015 as compared to 2014 was primarily due to the
	prepayment of certain debt issuances and declining balances of other debt, partially offset by interest expense on debt issued for the acquisition of new aircraft.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Miscellaneous, net included losses of $80&nbsp;million and $462&nbsp;million from fuel derivatives not qualifying for hedge accounting in 2015 and 2014, respectively. Foreign currency losses were
	approximately $129&nbsp;million and $41&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively. Foreign currency results included $61&nbsp;million and $10&nbsp;million of foreign exchange losses for 2015 and 2014, respectively, related to the Company&#146;s
	cash holdings in Venezuela. Miscellaneous, net for 2015 includes a $134&nbsp;million special charge related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unamortized
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	debt discounts for
	the early redemption of the 2026 Notes and the 2028 Notes. 2014 Miscellaneous, net includes a $64&nbsp;million debt extinguishment charge related to the retirement of the $248&nbsp;million 6% Convertible Junior Subordinated Debentures due 2030.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had $4.4&nbsp;billion in unrestricted cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments, a decrease of $0.8&nbsp;billion from December&nbsp;31, 2015. The Company
	had its entire commitment capacity of $1.35&nbsp;billion under the Credit Agreement available for letters of credit or borrowings as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had $124&nbsp;million of restricted cash and
	cash equivalents, which is primarily collateral for letters of credit and estimated future workers&#146; compensation claims. We may be required to post significant additional cash collateral to provide security for obligations. Restricted cash and
	cash equivalents at December&nbsp;31, 2015 totaled $206&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have a significant amount of fixed obligations, including debt,
	aircraft leases and financings, leases of airport property and other facilities and pension funding obligations. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	35
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	approximately $11.7&nbsp;billion of debt and capital lease obligations, including $1.0&nbsp;billion that are due within the next 12 months. In addition, we have substantial noncancelable
	commitments for capital expenditures, including the acquisition of new aircraft and related spare engines. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, our current liabilities exceeded our current assets by approximately $5.0&nbsp;billion. However, approximately
	$5.9&nbsp;billion of our current liabilities are related to our advance ticket sales and frequent flyer deferred revenue, both of which largely represent revenue to be recognized for travel in the near future and not actual cash outlays. The deficit
	in working capital does not have an adverse impact to our cash flows, liquidity or operations. The Company made principal payments of debt and capital lease obligations totaling $1.4&nbsp;billion in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company will continue to evaluate opportunities to prepay its debt, including open market repurchases, to reduce its indebtedness and related
	interest.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For 2017, the Company expects between $4.2&nbsp;billion and $4.4&nbsp;billion of gross capital expenditures. See Notes 11 and 15 to
	the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information on commitments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, a
	substantial portion of the Company&#146;s assets, principally aircraft, route authorities, airport slots and loyalty program intangible assets, was pledged under various loan and other agreements. We must sustain our profitability and/or access the
	capital markets to meet our significant long-term debt and capital lease obligations and future commitments for capital expenditures, including the acquisition of aircraft and related spare engines. See Note 11 to the financial statements included
	in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information on assets provided as collateral by the Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a discussion of
	the Company&#146;s sources and uses of cash from 2014 through 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash flow provided
	by operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $5.5&nbsp;billion compared to $6.0&nbsp;billion in the same period in 2015. Working capital changes reduced cash flow from operations by $0.5&nbsp;billion year-over-year in 2016 as compared
	to 2015. The following were significant working capital items in 2016:
</FONT>
</P>

</I>

	before income taxes and a $0.4&nbsp;billion increase in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	items for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to the same period in 2014. Working capital changes reduced cash flow from
	operations by $0.1&nbsp;billion year-over-year in 2015 as compared to 2014. The following were significant working capital items in 2015:

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Cash Flows from Investing Activities
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	2016 compared to 2015
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s capital expenditures were $3.2&nbsp;billion and
	$2.7&nbsp;billion in 2016
<I>
</I>
	and 2015, respectively. The Company&#146;s capital expenditures for both years were primarily attributable to the purchase of aircraft, facility and fleet-related costs and the purchase of information technology
	assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	2015 compared to 2014
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s capital expenditures were $2.7&nbsp;billion and $2.0&nbsp;billion in 2015
<I>
</I>
	and 2014, respectively. The Company&#146;s capital
	expenditures for both years were primarily attributable to the purchase of aircraft, facility and fleet-related costs. In 2015, the Company announced a strategic partnership with Azul. Through a wholly-owned subsidiary, the Company invested
	$100&nbsp;million for an economic stake of approximately five percent in Azul, Brazil&#146;s largest carrier by cities served, which provides a range of customer benefits including codesharing of flights, joint loyalty program participation and
	expanded connection opportunities on routes between the U.S. and Brazil, a key market for United, in addition to other points in North and South America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Cash Flows from Financing Activities
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Significant financing events in 2016 were as
	follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Share Repurchases
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company used $2.6&nbsp;billion of cash to purchase 50&nbsp;million shares of its common stock during 2016 under its share repurchase programs. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has
	$1.8&nbsp;billion remaining to spend under its share repurchase program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Debt Issuances
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, United completed two enhanced equipment trust certificate (&#147;EETC&#148;) offerings for a total principal amount of
	$2.0&nbsp;billion. Of the $2.0&nbsp;billion, United received and recorded $708&nbsp;million of proceeds as debt as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 to finance the purchase of 17 aircraft. United expects to receive all proceeds from the pass-through trusts
	by the end of the second quarter of 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, United borrowed approximately $369&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount
	from various financial institutions to finance the purchase of several aircraft delivered in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Debt and Capital Lease Principal
	Payments
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company made debt and capital lease principal payments of $1.4&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Significant financing events in 2015 were as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Share Repurchases
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company used $1.2&nbsp;billion of cash to purchase
	21&nbsp;million shares of its common stock during 2015 under its share repurchase programs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Debt Issuances
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During 2015, United issued $1.4&nbsp;billion of debt related to EETC offerings to finance aircraft.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

	purchase of several aircraft delivered in 2015.
</FONT>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United retired, at par, the entire $800&nbsp;million principal balance of its 6.75% Senior Secured Notes.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Financing Activities Not Affecting Cash
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	UAL amended its revolving credit facility under the Credit Agreement, increasing the capacity from $1.0&nbsp;billion to $1.35&nbsp;billion and establishing the maturity date for $1.315&nbsp;billion in
	lender commitments as January&nbsp;2, 2019.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:2%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	UAL issued approximately 17&nbsp;million shares in exchange for, or conversion of,
	$260&nbsp;million of convertible notes and retired the notes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For additional information regarding these Liquidity and Capital Resource
	matters, see Notes 3, 11, 13 and 14 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report. For information regarding
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	investing and financing activities, see the Company&#146;s
	statements of consolidated cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other significant financing event was as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<U>
	Debt Issuance
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In January 2017, United
	issued $300&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 5% Senior Notes due February&nbsp;1, 2024. See Note 11 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	38
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Contractual Obligations.
</I>
</B>
	The Company&#146;s business is capital intensive, requiring significant amounts of
	capital to fund the acquisition of assets, particularly aircraft. In the past, the Company has funded the acquisition of aircraft through outright purchase, by issuing debt, by entering into capital or operating leases, or through vendor financings.
	The Company also often enters into long-term lease commitments with airports to ensure access to terminal, cargo, maintenance and other required facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The table below provides a summary of the Company&#146;s material contractual obligations as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 (in billions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Long-term debt presented in the Company&#146;s financial statements is net of $124&nbsp;million of debt discount, premiums and debt issuance costs which are being
	amortized over the debt terms. Contractual payments are not net of the debt discount, premiums and debt issuance costs.
</FONT>
</TD>

	$44&nbsp;million in 2021 and $339&nbsp;million thereafter. Future interest payments on variable rate debt are estimated using estimated future variable rates based on a yield curve.
</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(c)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Represents our estimates of future minimum noncancelable commitments under our CPAs and does not include the portion of the underlying obligations for aircraft and
	facility rent that is disclosed as part of aircraft and nonaircraft operating leases. Amounts also exclude a portion of United&#146;s capital lease obligation recorded for certain of its CPAs. See Note 13 to the financial statements included in
	Part&nbsp;II, Item 8 of this report for the significant assumptions used to estimate the payments.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(d)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Amounts represent postretirement benefit payments, net of subsidy receipts, through 2026. Benefit payments approximate plan contributions as plans are substantially
	unfunded.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(e)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Represents estimate of the minimum funding requirements as determined by government regulations for United&#146;s material pension plans. Amounts are subject to change
	based on numerous assumptions, including the performance of assets in the plan and bond rates. See Critical Accounting Policies, below, for a discussion of our current year assumptions regarding United&#146;s pension plans.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	(f)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Represents contractual commitments for firm order aircraft, spare engines and other capital purchase commitments. See Note 15 to the financial statements included in
	Part II, Item 8 of this report for a discussion of our purchase commitments.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Balance
</FONT>
	Sheet Arrangements.
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
	An
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance
</FONT>
	sheet
	arrangement is any transaction, agreement or other contractual arrangement involving an unconsolidated entity under which a company has (1)&nbsp;made guarantees, (2)&nbsp;a retained or a contingent interest in transferred assets, (3)&nbsp;an
	obligation under derivative instruments classified as equity, or (4)&nbsp;any obligation arising out of a material variable interest in an unconsolidated entity that provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk support, or that engages
	in leasing, hedging or research and development arrangements. The Company&#146;s primary
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance
</FONT>
	sheet arrangements include operating leases, which are summarized in the contractual obligations table in
<I>
	Contractual Obligations,
</I>
	above,
<I>
</I>
	and certain municipal bond obligations, as discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United
	had cash collateralized $72&nbsp;million of letters of credit. United also had $383&nbsp;million of surety bonds securing various obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Most of the letters of credit have evergreen clauses and are expected to be
	renewed on an annual basis and the surety bonds have expiration dates through 2021.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United is the guarantor of
	approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion in aggregate principal amount of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	special facilities revenue bonds and interest thereon.&nbsp;These bonds, issued by various airport municipalities, are payable solely
	from rentals paid under long-term agreements with the respective governing bodies. The leasing arrangements associated with a majority of these obligations are accounted for as operating leases. The leasing arrangements associated with a portion of
	these obligations are accounted for as capital leases. The annual lease payments for those obligations accounted for as operating leases are included in the operating lease payments in the contractual obligations table above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United is the guarantor of $168&nbsp;million of aircraft mortgage debt issued by one of United&#146;s regional carriers. The
	aircraft mortgage debt is subject to increased cost provisions and the Company would potentially be responsible for those costs under the guarantees. The increased cost provisions in the $168&nbsp;million of aircraft mortgage debt are similar to
	those in certain of the Company&#146;s debt agreements. See Note 15 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information on increased cost provisions related to the Company&#146;s debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	EETCs.
</I>
</B>
	In June 2016 and September 2016, United completed two separate EETC offerings for a total principal amount of $2.0&nbsp;billion.
	United has received and recorded $708&nbsp;million of the proceeds from these offerings as debt as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. See Notes 11 and 14 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information on
	EETC pass-through trusts and variable interest entity consideration.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Increased Cost Provisions.
</I>
</B>
	See Note 15 to the financial
	statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for additional information on increased cost provisions related to the Company&#146;s debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Fuel Consortia.
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
	United participates in numerous fuel consortia with other air carriers at major airports to reduce the costs of fuel distribution and storage. Interline agreements
	govern the rights and responsibilities of the consortia members and provide for the allocation of the overall costs to operate the consortia based on usage. The consortia (and in limited cases, the participating carriers) have entered into long-term
	agreements to lease certain airport fuel storage and distribution facilities that are typically financed through
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	bonds (either special facilities lease revenue bonds or general airport revenue
	bonds), issued by various local municipalities. In general, each consortium lease agreement requires the consortium to make lease payments in amounts sufficient
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	40
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	to pay the maturing principal and interest payments on the bonds. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion principal amount of such bonds were secured by significant fuel
	facility leases in which United participates, as to which United and each of the signatory airlines has provided indirect guarantees of the debt. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s contingent exposure was approximately
	$234&nbsp;million principal amount of such bonds based on its recent consortia participation. The Company&#146;s contingent exposure could increase if the participation of other air carriers decreases. The guarantees will expire when the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	bonds are paid in full, which ranges from 2017 to 2049. The Company did not record a liability at the time these indirect guarantees were made. See Note 15 to the financial statements included in Part II,
	Item 8 of this report for additional information related to the Company&#146;s fuel consortia.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Critical accounting policies are defined as those that are affected by significant judgments and uncertainties which potentially could
	result in materially different accounting under different assumptions and conditions. The Company has prepared the financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (&#147;GAAP&#148;),
	which requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements. Actual results could differ from those estimates under different assumptions or conditions. The Company has identified the
	following critical accounting policies that impact the preparation of the financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Revenue Recognition.
</I>
</B>
	The Company
	records passenger ticket sales and tickets sold by other airlines for use on United as passenger revenue when the transportation is provided or upon estimated breakage. The value of unused passenger tickets is included in current liabilities as
	Advance ticket sales. Tickets sold by other airlines are recorded at the estimated values to be billed to the other airlines. Differences between amounts billed and the actual amounts may be rejected and rebilled or written off if the amount
	recorded was different from the original estimate. When necessary, the Company records a reserve against its interline billings and payables if historical experience indicates that these amounts are different.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-refundable
</FONT>
	tickets generally expire on the date of the intended flight, unless the date is extended by notification from the customer on or before the intended flight date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fees charged in association with changes or extensions to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-refundable
</FONT>
	tickets are recorded as other revenue at
	the time the fee is incurred. The fare on the changed ticket, including any additional collection of fare, is deferred and recognized in accordance with our transportation revenue recognition policy at the time the transportation is provided. Change
	fees related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-refundable
</FONT>
	tickets are considered a separate transaction from the air transportation because they represent a charge for the Company&#146;s additional service to modify a previous sale.
	Therefore, the pricing of the change fee and the initial customer order are separately determined and represent distinct earnings processes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company records an estimate of breakage revenue on the flight date for tickets that will expire unused. These estimates are based on the evaluation of
	actual historical results and forecasted trends. Refundable tickets expire after one year from the date of issuance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Financial Accounting
	Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) amended the FASB Accounting Standards Codification and created a new Topic 606,
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers
</I>
	. This amendment prescribes that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer
	of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. The amendment supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in Topic 605,
<I>
	Revenue Recognition,
</I>
	and most industry-specific guidance throughout the Industry Topics of the Accounting Standards Codification. The Company currently plans to use the full-retrospective approach in adopting this standard on January&nbsp;1,
	2018. Under the new standard, certain airline ancillary fees directly related to passenger revenue tickets, such as ticket change fees and baggage fees, are likely to no longer be considered distinct performance obligations separate from the
	passenger travel component. In addition, the ticket change fees which were previously recognized when received and booking fees when paid, will likely be recognized when transportation is provided. The Company
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	41
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	has previously recorded ancillary fees and change fees in other operating revenue but will record these in passenger revenue under the new standard. The Company is evaluating other possible
	impacts from the new standard on its consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Frequent Flyer Accounting.
</I>
</B>
	The Company&#146;s
	MileagePlus program is designed to increase customer loyalty. Program participants earn miles by flying on United and certain other participating airlines. Program participants can also earn miles through purchases from other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-airline
</FONT>
	partners that participate in the Company&#146;s loyalty program. We sell miles to these partners, which include credit card issuers, retail merchants, hotels, car rental companies and our participating
	airline partners. Miles can be redeemed for free (other than taxes and government imposed fees), discounted or upgraded air travel and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-travel
</FONT>
	awards. The Company records its obligation for future award
	redemptions using a deferred revenue model.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	When frequent flyers earn miles for flights, the Company recognizes a portion of the ticket sales
	as revenue when the air transportation occurs and defers a portion of the ticket sale representing the value of the related miles as a multiple-deliverable revenue arrangement. The Company determines the estimated selling price of air transportation
	and miles as if each element is sold on a separate basis. The total consideration from each ticket sale is then allocated to each of these elements, individually, on a pro rata basis. The miles are recorded in Frequent flyer deferred revenue on the
	Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet and recognized into revenue when the transportation is provided.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s estimated
	selling price of miles is based on an equivalent ticket value less fulfillment discount, which incorporates the expected redemption of miles, as the best estimate of selling price for these miles. The equivalent ticket value is based on the prior 12
	months&#146; weighted average equivalent ticket value of similar fares as those used to settle award redemptions while taking into consideration such factors as redemption pattern, cabin class, loyalty status and geographic region. The estimated
	selling price of miles is adjusted by a fulfillment discount that considers a number of factors, including redemption patterns of various customer groups.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United has a significant contract to sell MileagePlus miles to its
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-branded
</FONT>
	credit card partner, Chase. United identified the following significant revenue
	elements in its Second Amended and Restated
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-Branded
</FONT>
	Card Marketing Services Agreement (the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	&#147;Co-Brand
</FONT>
	Agreement&#148;): the air transportation element represented
	by the value of the mile (generally resulting from its redemption for future air transportation and whose fair value is described above); use of the United brand and access to MileagePlus member lists; advertising; and other travel related benefits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value of the elements is determined using management&#146;s estimated selling price of each element. The objective of using the
	estimated selling price based methodology is to determine the price at which we would transact a sale if the product or service were sold on a stand-alone basis. Accordingly, we determine our best estimate of selling price by considering multiple
	inputs and methods including, but not limited to, discounted cash flows, brand value, volume discounts, published selling prices, number of miles awarded and number of miles redeemed. The Company estimated the selling prices and volumes over the
	term of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-Brand
</FONT>
	Agreement in order to determine the allocation of proceeds to each of the multiple elements to be delivered. We also evaluate volumes on an annual basis, which may result in a change in
	the allocation of estimated selling price on a prospective basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company records passenger revenue related to the air transportation
	element when the transportation is delivered. The other elements are generally recognized as Other operating revenue when earned.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company
	accounts for miles sold and awarded that will never be redeemed by program members, which we refer to as breakage. The Company reviews its breakage estimates annually based upon the latest available information regarding redemption and expiration
	patterns. Miles expire after 18 months of member account inactivity. The Company&#146;s estimate of the expected expiration of miles requires significant management judgment. Current and future changes to expiration assumptions or to the expiration
	policy, or to program rules and program redemption opportunities, may result in material changes to the deferred revenue balance as well as recognized revenues from the programs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	42
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>

	liability:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Long-Lived Assets.
</I>
</B>
	The net book value of operating property and equipment for the Company was
	$23&nbsp;billion and $22&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. The assets&#146; recorded value is impacted by a number of accounting policy elections, including the estimation of useful lives and residual values and, when
	necessary, the recognition of asset impairment charges.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company records assets acquired, including aircraft, at acquisition cost.
	Depreciable life is determined through economic analysis, such as reviewing existing fleet plans, obtaining appraisals and comparing estimated lives to other airlines that operate similar fleets. As aircraft technology has improved, useful life has
	increased and the Company has generally estimated the lives of those aircraft to be 30&nbsp;years. Residual values are estimated based on historical experience with regard to the sale of both aircraft and spare parts and are established in
	conjunction with the estimated useful lives of the related fleets. Residual values are based on when the aircraft are acquired and typically reflect asset values that have not reached the end of their physical life. Both depreciable lives and
	residual values are revised periodically as facts and circumstances arise to recognize changes in the Company&#146;s fleet plan and other relevant information. A
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	increase in the average depreciable
	life of the Company&#146;s flight equipment would reduce annual depreciation expense on flight equipment by approximately $57&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company evaluates the carrying value of long-lived assets and intangible assets subject to amortization whenever events or changes in circumstances
	indicate that an impairment may exist. For purposes of this testing, the Company has generally identified the aircraft fleet type as the lowest level of identifiable cash flows for purposes of testing aircraft for impairment. An impairment charge is
	recognized when the asset&#146;s carrying value exceeds its net undiscounted future cash flows and its fair market value. The amount of the charge is the difference between the asset&#146;s carrying value and fair market value.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, the Company determined that the FAA&#146;s action impaired the entire value of its Newark slots because the slots no longer were the mechanism
	that governed
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	take-off
</FONT>
	and landing rights, and the Company recorded a special charge to write off the intangible asset. See Notes 16 to the financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this report for
	additional information.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Benefit Plan Accounting.
</I>
</B>
	We sponsor defined benefit pension plans for eligible employees and
	retirees. The most critical assumptions impacting our defined benefit pension plan obligations and expenses are the weighted average discount rate and the expected long-term rate of return on the plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United&#146;s pension plans&#146; under-funded status was $1.9&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Funding requirements for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-qualified
</FONT>
	defined benefit pension plans are determined by government regulations. In 2017, we anticipate contributing at least $400&nbsp;million to our pension plans. The fair value of the plans&#146; assets was
	$3.4&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	When calculating pension expense for 2017, the Company assumed that its plans&#146; assets would
	generate a long-term rate of return of approximately 7.0%. The expected long-term rate of return assumption was developed based on historical experience and input from the trustee managing the plans&#146; assets.
<B>
</B>
	&nbsp;The expected long-term
	rate of return on plan assets is based on a target allocation of assets, which is based on a goal of earning the highest rate of return while maintaining risk at acceptable levels. Our projected long-term rate of return reflects the active
	management of our plans&#146; assets.&nbsp;The plans strive to have assets sufficiently diversified so that adverse or unexpected results from one security class will not have an unduly detrimental impact on the entire portfolio.&nbsp;Plan
	fiduciaries regularly review actual asset allocation and the pension plans&#146; investments are periodically rebalanced to the targeted allocation when considered appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	43
</FONT>
</P>

	The defined benefit pension plans&#146; assets consist of return generating investments and risk mitigating
	investments which are held through direct ownership or through interests in common collective trusts.&nbsp;Return generating investments include primarily equity securities, fixed-income securities and alternative investments (e.g. private equity
	and hedge funds). Risk mitigating investments include primarily U.S. government and investment grade corporate fixed-income securities. The allocation of assets was as follows at December&nbsp;31, 2016:
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
