</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the first quarter of 2017, the Company announced that it will retire its fleet of Boeing 747 aircraft from scheduled
	service by the end of 2017. The Company does not expect there to be a material impact to depreciation and amortization expense.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, United had $1.3&nbsp;billion in financing available through EETC transactions for the financing of all of its aircraft deliveries scheduled in the first half of 2017. See Note 11 of this report for additional information on
	aircraft financing. The Company has also secured backstop financing commitments from certain of its aircraft manufacturers for a limited number of its future aircraft deliveries, subject to certain customary conditions. Financing may be necessary to
	satisfy the Company&#146;s capital commitments for its firm order aircraft and other related capital expenditures.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Legal and
	Environmental.
</I>
</B>
	The Company has certain contingencies resulting from litigation and claims incident to the ordinary course of business. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, management believes, after considering a number of factors, including (but
	not limited to) the information currently available, the views of legal counsel, the nature of contingencies to which the Company is subject and prior experience, that the ultimate disposition of the litigation and claims will not materially affect
	the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position or results of operations. The Company records liabilities for legal and environmental claims when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable. These amounts are recorded based on the Company&#146;s
	assessments of the likelihood of their eventual disposition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Guarantees and Indemnifications.
</I>
</B>
	In the normal course of business,
	the Company enters into numerous real estate leasing and aircraft financing arrangements that have various guarantees included in the contracts. These guarantees are primarily in the form of indemnities under which the Company typically indemnifies
	the lessors and any tax/financing parties against tort liabilities that arise out of the use, occupancy, operation or maintenance of the leased premises or financed aircraft. Currently, the Company believes that any future payments required under
	these guarantees or indemnities would be immaterial, as most tort liabilities and related indemnities are covered by insurance (subject to deductibles). Additionally, certain leased premises such as fueling stations or storage facilities include
	indemnities of such parties for any environmental liability that may arise out of or relate to the use of the leased premises.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, United is the guarantor of approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion in aggregate principal amount of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	special facilities revenue bonds and interest thereon. These bonds, issued by
	various airport municipalities, are payable solely from rentals paid under long-term agreements with the respective governing bodies. The leasing arrangements associated with $1.4&nbsp;billion of these obligations are accounted for as operating
	leases with the associated expense recorded on a straight-line basis resulting in ratable accrual of the lease obligation over the expected lease term. These
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	special facilities revenue bonds are
	included in our lease commitments disclosed in Note 13 of this report. The leasing arrangements associated with $400&nbsp;million of these obligations are accounted for as capital leases. All of these bonds are due between 2017 and 2038.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	95
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage96"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In United&#146;s financing transactions that include loans, United typically agrees to reimburse lenders for
	any reduced returns with respect to the loans due to any change in capital requirements and, in the case of loans in which the interest rate is based on LIBOR, for certain other increased costs that the lenders incur in carrying these loans as a
	result of any change in law, subject, in most cases, to obligations of the lenders to take certain limited steps to mitigate the requirement for, or the amount of, such increased costs. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had $2.6&nbsp;billion of
	floating rate debt and $90&nbsp;million of fixed rate debt, with remaining terms of up to 12 years, that are subject to these increased cost provisions.&nbsp;In several financing transactions involving loans or leases from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	entities, with remaining terms of up to 12 years and an aggregate balance of $2.6
<B>
</B>
	&nbsp;billion, the Company bears the risk of any change in tax laws that would subject loan or lease payments
	thereunder to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	entities to withholding taxes, subject to customary exclusions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, United is the guarantor of $168&nbsp;million of aircraft mortgage debt issued by one of United&#146;s regional carriers. The aircraft mortgage debt is subject to similar increased cost provisions as described above for the
	Company&#146;s debt and the Company would potentially be responsible for those costs under the guarantees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Fuel Consortia.
</I>
</B>
	United participates in numerous fuel consortia with other air carriers at major airports to reduce the costs of fuel distribution and storage. Interline agreements govern the rights and responsibilities of the consortia members and provide
	for the allocation of the overall costs to operate the consortia based on usage. The consortia (and in limited cases, the participating carriers) have entered into long-term agreements to lease certain airport fuel storage and distribution
	facilities that are typically financed through
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	bonds (either special facilities lease revenue bonds or general airport revenue bonds), issued by various local municipalities. In general, each
	consortium lease agreement requires the consortium to make lease payments in amounts sufficient to pay the maturing principal and interest payments on the bonds. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion principal amount of such
	bonds were secured by significant fuel facility leases in which United participates, as to which United and each of the signatory airlines has provided indirect guarantees of the debt. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s contingent
	exposure was approximately $234&nbsp;million principal amount of such bonds based on its recent consortia participation. The Company&#146;s contingent exposure could increase if the participation of other air carriers decreases. The guarantees will
	expire when the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	bonds are paid in full, which ranges from 2017 to 2049. The Company did not record a liability at the time these indirect guarantees were made.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Regional Capacity Purchase.
</I>
</B>
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United had 223 call options to purchase regional jet aircraft being operated by
	certain regional carriers. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, none of the call options were exercisable because none of the required conditions to make an option exercisable by United was met.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Credit Card Processing Agreements.
</I>
</B>
	The Company has agreements with financial institutions that process customer credit card transactions for the sale of air travel and other services. Under
	certain of the Company&#146;s credit card processing agreements, the financial institutions in certain circumstances have the right to require that the Company maintain a reserve equal to a portion of advance ticket sales that has been processed by
	that financial institution, but for which the Company has not yet provided the air transportation. Such financial institutions may require additional cash or other collateral reserves to be established or additional withholding of payments related
	to receivables collected if the Company does not maintain certain minimum levels of unrestricted cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments (collectively, &#147;Unrestricted Liquidity&#148;). The Company&#146;s current level of Unrestricted
	Liquidity is substantially in excess of these minimum levels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Labor Negotiations.
</I>
</B>
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, United,
	including its subsidiaries, had approximately 88,000 employees. Approximately 80% of United&#146;s employees were represented by various U.S. labor organizations as of December&nbsp;31, 2016
<B>
	.
</B>
	In January 2016, United&#146;s pilots, represented
	by the Air Line Pilots Association, International (&#147;ALPA&#148;), agreed to extend their contract through January&nbsp;31, 2019. In March 2016, the Company&#146;s dispatchers, represented by the Professional Airline Flight Control Association,
	agreed to extend their current contract through 2021. In April 2016, the fleet service, passenger service, storekeeper and other employees represented by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (&#147;IAM&#148;) ratified
	seven new contracts with the Company which extended the contracts through 2021. In August 2016, United&#146;s
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	96
</FONT>
</P>

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	flight attendants, represented by the AFA, ratified a five-year joint collective bargaining agreement through 2021. In December 2016, the technicians and related employees, represented by the
	IBT, ratified a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	six-year
</FONT>
	joint collective bargaining agreement which extended the contract through 2022. The agreements with ALPA and IBT contain provisions that require the Company to align contract terms
	with other airlines&#146; workgroups under certain conditions.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
<U>
	2016
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In April 2016, the Federal Aviation Administration (&#147;FAA&#148;) announced that it will designate Newark Liberty International Airport (&#147;Newark&#148;)&nbsp;as a Level&nbsp;2 schedule-facilitated
	airport under the International Air Transport Association Worldwide Slot Guidelines effective October&nbsp;30, 2016. The designation was associated with an updated demand and capacity analysis of Newark by the FAA.&nbsp;In 2016, the Company
	determined that the FAA&#146;s action impaired the entire value of its Newark slots because the slots are no longer the mechanism that governs
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	take-off
</FONT>
	and landing rights. Accordingly, the Company recorded a
	$412&nbsp;million special charge ($264&nbsp;million net of taxes) to write off the intangible asset.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, the City of Cleveland agreed to
	amend the Company&#146;s lease, which runs through 2029, associated with certain excess airport terminal space (principally Terminal D) and related facilities at Hopkins International Airport (&#147;Cleveland&#148;). The Company recorded an accrual
	for remaining payments under the lease for facilities that the Company no longer uses and will continue to incur costs under the lease without economic benefit to the Company. This liability was measured and recorded at its fair value when the
	Company ceased its right to use such facilities leased to it pursuant to the lease. The Company recorded a net charge of $74&nbsp;million ($47&nbsp;million net of taxes) related to the amended lease.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fleet service, passenger service, storekeeper and other employees represented by the IAM ratified seven new contracts with the Company which extended
	the contracts through 2021. The technicians and related employees represented by the IBT ratified a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	six-year
</FONT>
	joint collective bargaining agreement which extended the contract through 2022. During 2016, the
	Company recorded $171&nbsp;million ($110&nbsp;million net of taxes) of special charges primarily for payments in conjunction with the IAM and IBT agreements described above. As part of the ratified
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	97
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage98"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	contract with the IBT, the Company amended some of its technicians and related employees&#146; postretirement medical plans. The amendments triggered curtailment accounting, resulting in the
	recognition of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	$60&nbsp;million gain ($38&nbsp;million net of taxes) for accelerated recognition of a prior service credit in one of the plans. Also, as part of the ratified contract with the AFA,
	the Company amended two of its flight attendant postretirement medical plans. The amendments triggered curtailment accounting, resulting in the recognition of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	$47&nbsp;million gain ($30&nbsp;million
	net of taxes) for accelerated recognition of a prior service credit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During 2016, the Company recorded $37&nbsp;million ($24&nbsp;million net
	of taxes) of severance and benefit costs related to a voluntary
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	early-out
</FONT>
	program for the Company&#146;s flight attendants and other severance agreements. In 2014, more than 2,500 flight attendants elected to
	voluntarily separate from the Company for a severance payment, with a maximum value of $100,000 per participant, based on years of service, with retirement dates through the end of 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During 2016, the Company recorded gains and losses on sale of assets and other special charges of $51&nbsp;million ($33&nbsp;million net of taxes). In addition, the Company recorded $8&nbsp;million
	($5&nbsp;million net of taxes) of losses due to exchange rate changes in Venezuela applicable to funds held in local currency and recorded a $9&nbsp;million ($6&nbsp;million net of taxes) gain on the sale of an affiliate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
<U>
	2015
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During its annual
	assessment in the fourth quarter, the Company recorded $33&nbsp;million ($22&nbsp;million net of related income tax benefit) related to the impairment of its indefinite-lived intangible assets (certain domestic slots and international Pacific
	routes), $8&nbsp;million for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unexercised aircraft purchase options and $7&nbsp;million for inventory held for sale. For the full-year 2015, the Company also recorded other impairments,
	including $10&nbsp;million for discontinued internal software projects and $10&nbsp;million for the impairment of several engines held for sale.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company recorded $107&nbsp;million of severance and benefit costs primarily related to a voluntary
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	early-out
</FONT>
	program for its flight attendants. In 2014, more than 2,500 flight attendants elected to voluntarily separate from the Company for a severance payment, with a maximum value of $100,000 per participant, based on years of service, with retirement
	dates through the end of 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During 2015, the Company also recorded $18&nbsp;million related to collective bargaining agreements,
	$60&nbsp;million of integration-related costs primarily related to systems integration and training for employees, $32&nbsp;million related to charges for settlements in connection with legal matters, $16&nbsp;million for the cease use of an
	aircraft under lease and $14&nbsp;million for losses on the sale of aircraft and other miscellaneous gains and losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company recorded
	$202&nbsp;million of losses as part of Nonoperating income (expense): Miscellaneous, net due primarily to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of $134&nbsp;million related to the unamortized
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	debt discount from the extinguishment of the 6% Notes due 2026 and the 6% Notes due 2028. During 2015, the Company also recorded a $61&nbsp;million foreign exchange loss related to its cash holdings
	in Venezuela. The Venezuelan government has maintained currency controls and fixed official exchange rates (i.e. Sistema Complementario de Administracion de Divisas (&#147;SICAD&#148;), and Sistema Marginal de Divisas (&#147;SIMADI&#148;)) for many
	years.&nbsp;Previously, airlines were permitted to use the more favorable SICAD rate (13.5 Venezuelan bolivars to one U.S. dollar) if repatriating profits and for payments of local goods and services in Venezuela. During 2015, many of the payments
	for local goods and services transitioned to utilizing the SIMADI rate (200 Venezuelan bolivars to one U.S. dollar) or were required to be paid in U.S. dollars. Furthermore, the Venezuelan government has not permitted the exchange and repatriations
	of local currency since
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-2014.&nbsp;As
</FONT>
	a result, the Company changed the exchange rate from historical SICAD rates to a combination of SIMADI and SICAD rates based on projections of future cash
	payments.&nbsp;Including this adjustment, the Company&#146;s resulting cash balance held in Venezuelan bolivars at December&nbsp;31, 2015 was approximately $13&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	98
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage99"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
<U>
	2014
</U>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company recorded a charge of $16&nbsp;million ($10&nbsp;million net of related income tax benefits) related to its annual assessment of impairment of its indefinite-lived intangible assets (certain
	international Pacific routes). The Company also recorded $33&nbsp;million for charges related primarily to impairment of its flight equipment held for disposal associated with its Boeing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	737-300
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	737-500
</FONT>
	fleets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company recorded $141&nbsp;million of severance and benefit costs related primarily to a
	voluntary
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	early-out
</FONT>
	program for its flight attendants. More than 2,500 participants elected a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	opportunity to voluntarily separate from the Company for a
	severance payment, with a maximum value of $100,000 per participant, based on years of service, with retirement dates through the end of 2016. In addition, the Company recorded $58&nbsp;million of severance and benefits primarily related to
	reductions of management and front-line employees, including from Cleveland, as part of its cost savings initiatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company recorded
	$66&nbsp;million for the permanent grounding of 21 of the Company&#146;s Embraer ERJ 135 regional aircraft under lease through 2018, which included an accrual for remaining lease payments and an amount for maintenance return conditions. The Company
	decided to permanently ground these 21 Embraer ERJ 135 aircraft as a result of new Embraer E175 regional jet deliveries, the impact of pilot shortages at regional carriers and fuel prices. The Company also recorded $33&nbsp;million for losses on the
	sale of assets and other special charges. In addition, $96&nbsp;million of integration-related costs included compensation costs related to systems integration, training, severance and relocation for employees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United used cash to retire, at par, the entire $248&nbsp;million principal balance of the 6% Convertible Debentures and the 6% Convertible Preferred
	Securities, Term Income Deferrable Equity Securities (TIDES) and incurred $64&nbsp;million of expense primarily associated with the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of the related
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	debt discounts. The Company also recorded $10&nbsp;million of foreign exchange losses in Venezuela in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s accrual and payment activity is primarily related to severance and other compensation expense
	associated with voluntary employee early retirement programs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	NOTE 17 - SEGMENT INFORMATION
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating segments are defined as components of an enterprise with separate financial information, which are evaluated regularly by the chief operating
	decision maker and are used in resource allocation and performance assessments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	99
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage100"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company deploys its aircraft across its route network through a single route scheduling system to
	maximize its value. When making resource allocation decisions, the Company&#146;s chief operating decision maker evaluates flight profitability data, which considers aircraft type and route economics. The Company&#146;s chief operating decision
	maker makes resource allocation decisions to maximize the Company&#146;s consolidated financial results. Managing the Company as one segment allows management the opportunity to maximize the value of its route network.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s operating revenue by principal geographic region (as defined by the U.S. Department of Transportation) for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31 is presented in the table below (in millions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company attributes revenue among the geographic areas based upon the origin and destination of each flight segment.
	The Company&#146;s operations involve an insignificant level of dedicated revenue-producing assets in geographic regions as the overwhelming majority of the Company&#146;s revenue producing assets (primarily U.S. registered aircraft) can be deployed
	in any of its geographic regions.
</FONT>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	UAL&#146;s quarterly financial data is subject to seasonal fluctuations and historically its second and
	third quarter financial results, which reflect higher travel demand, are better than its first and fourth quarter financial results. UAL&#146;s quarterly results were impacted by the following significant items (in millions):
</FONT>

<A NAME="FIS_ACCOUNTING_CHANGES"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

<EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<A NAME="FIS_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="15%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D300268D10K_HTM_TX300268_16">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;9A.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Evaluation
	of Disclosure Control and Procedures
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	UAL and United each maintain controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that information
	required to be disclosed in the reports filed or submitted by UAL and United to the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, within the time periods specified by the SEC&#146;s rules and
	forms, and is accumulated and communicated to management including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. The management of UAL and United, including the
	Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, performed an evaluation to conclude with reasonable assurance that UAL&#146;s and United&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures were designed and operating effectively to report the information
	each company is required to disclose in the reports they file with the SEC on a timely basis. Based on that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer of UAL and United have concluded that as of December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting during the Quarter Ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, there was no change in UAL&#146;s or United&#146;s
	internal control over financial reporting during their most recent fiscal quarter that materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, their internal control over financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	103
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents

</EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<EFX_AUDITORS_OPINION>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDITORS_OPINION_3"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	United Continental Holdings, Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have
	audited United Continental Holdings, Inc.&#146;s (the &#147;Company&#148;) internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of
	Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) (the &#147;COSO criteria&#148;). The Company&#146;s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the
	effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting in Item 9A. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company&#146;s internal control
	over financial reporting based on our audit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting
	Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audit included
	obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing
	such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial
	reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that
	(1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as
	necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors
	of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of
	any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, based
	on the COSO criteria.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States),
	the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 of the Company and our report dated February&nbsp;23, 2017 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	/s/ Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Chicago, Illinois
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	February&nbsp;23, 2017
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	104
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage105"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	United Continental Holdings, Inc. Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	February&nbsp;23, 2017
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To the
	Stockholders of United Continental Holdings, Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Chicago, Illinois
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The management of United Continental Holdings, Inc. (&#147;UAL&#148;) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in
	Exchange Act Rules
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	13a-15(f).
</FONT>
	Our internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial
	statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation
	of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the supervision and with the participation of management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, we conducted an
	evaluation of the design and operating effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. In making this assessment, management used the framework set forth in Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework
	(2013 Framework)
<I>
</I>
	issued by the Committee of the Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. Based on this evaluation, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that our internal control over financial
	reporting was effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our independent registered public accounting firm, Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, who
	audited UAL&#146;s consolidated financial statements included in this Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K,
</FONT>
	has issued a report on UAL&#146;s internal control over financial reporting, which is included herein.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	United Airlines, Inc. Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	February&nbsp;23, 2017
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To the Stockholder of United Airlines, Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Chicago, Illinois
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The management of United
	Airlines, Inc. (&#147;United&#148;) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Exchange Act Rules
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	13a-15(f).
</FONT>
	United&#146;s
	internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting
	principles. Because of its inherent limitations, our internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may
	become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under
	the supervision and with the participation of management, including United&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, United conducted an evaluation of the design and operating effectiveness of our internal control over financial
	reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. In making this assessment, management used the framework set forth in Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework (2013 Framework) issued by the Committee of the Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway
	Commission. Based on this evaluation, United&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	This annual report does not include an attestation report of United&#146;s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial
	reporting. Management&#146;s report was not subject to attestation by United&#146;s registered public accounting firm pursuant to the rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit United to provide only management&#146;s report in this
	annual report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	105
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_DIRECTORS_AND_OFFICERS>
<A NAME="FIS_DIRECTORS_AND_OFFICERS"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	ITEM&nbsp;10.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Certain information required by this item with respect to UAL is incorporated by reference from UAL&#146;s definitive proxy statement for its 2017 Annual Meeting of Stockholders. Information regarding the
	executive officers of UAL is presented below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Information required by this item with respect to United is omitted pursuant to General
	Instruction I(2)(c) of Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF UAL
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The executive officers of UAL as of February&nbsp;23, 2017 are listed below, along with their ages, tenure as officer and business background for at least
	the last five years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Michael P. Bonds.
</B>
	Age 54. Mr.&nbsp;Bonds has served as Executive Vice President Human Resources and Labor
	Relations of UAL and United since October 2010. From June 2005 to September 2010, Mr.&nbsp;Bonds served as Senior Vice President Human Resources and Labor Relations of Continental Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Continental&#148;). Mr.&nbsp;Bonds joined
	Continental in 1995.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Brett J. Hart.
</B>
	Age 47. Mr.&nbsp;Hart has served as Executive Vice President and General Counsel of UAL and United
	since February 2012. Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as acting Chief Executive Officer and principal executive officer of the Company, on an interim basis, from October 2015 to March 2016. From December 2010 to February 2012, he served as Senior Vice
	President, General Counsel and Secretary of UAL, United and Continental. From June 2009 to December 2010, Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Corporate Secretary at Sara Lee Corporation, a consumer food and beverage
	company. From March 2005 to May 2009, Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as Deputy General Counsel and Chief Global Compliance Officer of Sara Lee Corporation. Mr.&nbsp;Hart joined UAL in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Gregory L. Hart.
</B>
	Age 51. Mr.&nbsp;Hart has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer of UAL and United since February 2014. From December 2013 to February 2014, he served as
	Senior Vice President Operations of UAL and United. From September 2012 to December 2013, Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as Senior Vice President Technical Operations of United. From October 2010 to September 2012, Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as Senior Vice
	President Network of United and Continental. From September 2008 to September 2010, Mr.&nbsp;Hart served as Vice President Network Strategy of Continental. Mr.&nbsp;Hart joined Continental in 1997.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Linda P. Jojo.
</B>
	Age 51. Ms.&nbsp;Jojo has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer of UAL and United since November 2014.
	From July 2011 to October 2014, Ms.&nbsp;Jojo served as Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer of Rogers Communications, Inc., a Canadian communications and media company. From October 2008 to June 2011, Ms.&nbsp;Jojo served as Chief
	Information Officer of Energy Future Holdings, a Dallas-based privately held energy company and electrical utility provider.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Chris
	Kenny.
</B>
	Age 52. Mr.&nbsp;Kenny has served as Vice President and Controller of UAL and United since October 2010. From September 2003 to September 2010, Mr.&nbsp;Kenny served as Vice President and Controller of Continental. Mr.&nbsp;Kenny joined
	Continental in 1997.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	J. Scott Kirby. A
</B>
	ge 49. Mr.&nbsp;Kirby has served as President of UAL and United since August 2016. Prior to
	joining the Company, from December 2013 to August 2016, Mr.&nbsp;Kirby served as President of American Airlines Group and American Airlines, Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Kirby also previously served as President of US Airways from October 2006 to December 2013.
	Mr.&nbsp;Kirby held significant other leadership roles at US Airways and at America West prior to the 2005 merger of those carriers, including Executive Vice President&#151;Sales and Marketing (2001 to 2006); Senior Vice President,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	e-business
</FONT>
	(2000 to 2001); Vice President, Revenue Management (1998 to 2000);
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	106
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage107"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Vice President, Planning (1997 to 1998); and Senior Director, Scheduling and Planning (1995 to 1998). Prior to joining America West, Mr.&nbsp;Kirby worked for American Airlines Decision
	Technologies and at the Pentagon.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Andrew C. Levy.
</B>
	Age 47. Mr.&nbsp;Levy has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial
	Officer since August 2016. From November 2014 to August 2016, he was the Chief Executive Officer and Managing Partner of AML Ventures, LLC, an investment and advisory firm specializing in the airline industry. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Levy held
	leadership roles at Allegiant Travel Company (&#147;Allegiant&#148;) for thirteen years, including as Chief Operating Officer and a Director from September 2013 to October 2014; President from September 2009 to October 2014; Chief Financial Officer
	from October 2007 to May 2010; and Managing Director, Planning&nbsp;&amp; Treasurer from April 2001 to October 2010. Prior to joining Allegiant, Mr.&nbsp;Levy worked at Mpower Communications, Inc., Savoy Capital and ValuJet Airlines, Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Oscar Munoz.
</B>
	Age 58. Mr.&nbsp;Munoz has served as Chief Executive Officer since September 2015, and also as President from September
	2015 until August 2016. From February 2015 to September 2015, Mr.&nbsp;Munoz served as President and Chief Operating Officer of CSX Corporation (&#147;CSX&#148;), a railroad and intermodal transportation services company, overseeing operations,
	sales and marketing, human resources, service design and information technology. Prior to his appointment as President and Chief Operating Officer of CSX, Mr.&nbsp;Munoz served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of CSX
	Transportation from January&nbsp;2012 to February&nbsp;2015 and as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of CSX from 2003 to 2012.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Munoz has been a member of the UAL Board of Directors (&#147;Board of Directors&#148;)
	since 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	There are no family relationships among the executive officers or the directors of UAL. The executive officers are elected by the
	Board of Directors each year and hold office until the next annual meeting of stockholders, until their successors are elected and qualified, or until their earlier death, resignation or removal.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company has a code of ethics, the &#147;Ethics and Compliance Principles,&#148; for its directors, officers and employees. The code serves as a
	&#147;Code of Ethics&#148; as defined by SEC regulations, and as a &#147;Code of Business Conduct and Ethics&#148; under the listed Company Manual of the NYSE. The code is available on the Company&#146;s website at http://ir.united.com. Waivers
	granted to certain officers from compliance with or future amendments to the code will be disclosed on the Company&#146;s website in accordance with Item 5.05 of Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	8-K.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_DIRECTORS_AND_OFFICERS>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:14PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

</EFX_COMPENSATION>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:14PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<EFX_ACCOUNTANT_FEES>
<A NAME="FIS_ACCOUNTANT_FEES"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="15%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D300268D10K_HTM_TX300268_23">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;14.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	PRINCIPAL ACCOUNTANT FEES AND SERVICES.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Audit Committee of the Board of Directors has adopted a policy on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approval
</FONT>
	of services of the
	Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm. As a wholly-owned subsidiary of UAL, United&#146;s audit services are determined by UAL. The policy provides that the Audit Committee shall
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approve
</FONT>
	all audit and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-audit
</FONT>
	services to be provided to UAL and its subsidiaries and affiliates by its independent auditors. The process by which this is carried
	out is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For recurring services, the Audit Committee reviews and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approves
</FONT>
	the
	independent registered public accounting firm&#146;s annual audit services in conjunction with the annual appointment of the outside auditors. The reviewed materials include a description of the services along with related fees. The Audit Committee
	also reviews and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approves
</FONT>
	other classes of recurring services along with fee thresholds for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approved
</FONT>
	services. In the event that the additional services are
	required prior to the next scheduled Audit Committee meeting,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approvals
</FONT>
	of additional services follow the process described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Any requests for audit, audit related, tax and other services not contemplated with the recurring services approval described above must be submitted to the Audit Committee for specific
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approval
</FONT>
	and cannot commence until such approval has been granted. Normally,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approval
</FONT>
	is provided at regularly scheduled meetings. However, the authority to grant
	specific
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approval
</FONT>
	between meetings, as necessary, has been delegated to the Chair of the Audit Committee. The Chair must update the Audit Committee at the next regularly scheduled meeting of any services
	that were granted specific
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approval.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On a periodic basis, the Audit Committee reviews the status
	of services and fees incurred
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-to-date
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and a list of newly
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-approved
</FONT>
	services since its last regularly scheduled meeting.
	The Audit Committee has considered whether the 2016 and 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-audit
</FONT>
	services provided by Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm, are compatible with
	maintaining auditor independence.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	All of the services in 2016 and 2015 under the Audit Fees, Audit Related Fees, Tax Fees and All Other Fees
	categories below have been approved by the Audit Committee pursuant to paragraph (c)(7) of Rule
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2-01
</FONT>
	of Regulation
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	S-X
</FONT>
	of the Exchange Act.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The aggregate fees billed for professional services rendered by the Company&#146;s independent auditors in 2016 and 2015 are as follows (in thousands):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:16%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Note: UAL and United amounts are the same.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	AUDIT FEES
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For 2016 and 2015, audit fees consist primarily of the audit and quarterly reviews of the consolidated financial statements and the audit of the
	effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting of United Continental Holdings, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Audit fees also include the audit of the consolidated financial statements of United, employee benefit plan audits,
	attestation services required by statute or regulation, comfort letters, consents, assistance with and review of documents filed with the SEC, and accounting and financial reporting consultations and research work necessary to comply with generally
	accepted auditing standards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	108
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage109"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300268D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	AUDIT RELATED FEES
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For 2016 and 2015, fees for audit related services consisted of professional services related to due diligence and understanding key process changes and identifying and testing changes in the internal
	control environment prior to implementation of system conversions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	TAX FEES
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Tax fees for 2016 and 2015 include professional services provided for foreign and state tax returns, research and consultations regarding tax accounting,
	and tax compliance matters and assistance in assembling data to prepare for and respond to governmental reviews of past tax filings, exclusive of tax services rendered in connection with the audit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	ALL OTHER FEES
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:8PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fees for all
	other services billed in 2016 and 2015 consist of subscriptions to Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-line
</FONT>
	accounting research tool.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_ACCOUNTANT_FEES>
</EFX_PART_III>

	(a)

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT">
<TD HEIGHT="8">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2">
</TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2">

</TR>

	10-K

	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, formatted in XBRL (Extensible Business Reporting Language): (i) the Statements of Consolidated Operations, (ii)&nbsp;the Statements of Consolidated Comprehensive Income (Loss), (iii) the Consolidated
	Balance Sheets, (iv)&nbsp;the Statements of Consolidated Cash Flows, (v)&nbsp;the Statements of Consolidated Stockholders&#146; Equity (Deficit) and (vi)&nbsp;the Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">

	132

<DIV CLASS="eolNewPage"></DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage133"></A>
<A NAME="D300268DEX102_HTM"></A>
<EFX_EXHIBIT_10>
<A NAME="FIS_EXHIBIT_10"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<B>
	Exhibit 10.2
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:14PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	UNITED CONTINENTAL HOLDINGS, INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:14PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	PROFIT SHARING PLAN
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:12PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(Amended and Restated Effective January&nbsp;1, 2016,
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:12PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	Except As Otherwise Provided Herein)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:12PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	I.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<U>
	General
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	A.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Purpose.
</I>
	United Continental Holdings, Inc. (the &#147;Company&#148;) sponsors this United Continental Holdings, Inc. Profit Sharing Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) for the benefit of certain employees of United Air
	Lines, Inc., Continental Airlines, Inc., and other participating Affiliates.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	B.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Collective Bargaining.
</I>
	As it relates to Qualified Employees who are in the class or craft of employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement with the Employer pursuant to which the Employer has agreed to
	provide such Qualified Employees with participation in a profit sharing bonus plan, this Plan is maintained pursuant to such agreement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	C.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Cash Bonus Plan.
</I>
	The Plan is a cash bonus plan and is not intended to be (and will not be construed or administered as) an employee benefit plan within the meaning of ERISA. The Plan is intended to be a
	discretionary cash bonus plan and payments under the Plan will not constitute a part of an employee&#146;s regular rate of pay for any purpose; provided, however, all Awards will be paid to Qualified Employees in accordance with the terms of the
	Plan and the applicable collective bargaining agreements. Except to the extent specifically provided under a particular pension, insurance, profit sharing, retirement, welfare or other employee benefit plan or arrangement maintained or contributed
	to by the Company or an Affiliate, the payments to an employee under the Plan will not be treated as &#147;salary,&#148; &#147;wages,&#148; or &#147;cash compensation&#148; to the employee for the purpose of computing benefits to which the employee
	may be entitled under any such plan or arrangement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	D.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Effective Date
</I>
	. The Plan commenced on January&nbsp;1, 2006 as the UAL Corporation Success Sharing Program &#150; Profit Sharing Plan, was previously amended and restated effective January&nbsp;1, 2011, and again
	effective January&nbsp;1, 2014, and is hereby amended and restated effective January&nbsp;1, 2016, to incorporate the requirements of certain collective bargaining agreements. This amendment and restatement is effective for the 2016 Plan Year and
	future Plan Years, except as otherwise stated herein, and does not apply to 2015 Plan Year profit sharing payments made in 2016.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	E.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Term.
</I>
	The provisions of the Plan shall continue indefinitely subject to termination by the Company, or, as it relates to any Qualified Employees who are in the class or craft of employees covered by a collective
	bargaining agreement with the Employer pursuant to which the Employer has agreed to provide such Qualified Employees with participation in a profit sharing bonus plan, subject to termination pursuant to the terms of such collective bargaining
	agreement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	UCH&nbsp;PSP
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016&nbsp;(FINAL)
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<A NAME="eolPage134"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	F.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Definitions.
</I>
	Unless otherwise specified, the capitalized terms under the Plan have the meanings given below:
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Affiliate
</I>
	. &#147;Affiliate&#148; means any entity, corporate or otherwise, in which the Company, directly or indirectly,
	owns or controls a greater than 80% interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Award.
</I>
	&#147;Award&#148; means the dollar value of the award payable
	to a Qualified Employee for an Award Year as determined under the Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Award Year
</I>
	. &#147;Award Year&#148; means
	the Plan Year for which a profit sharing Award, if any, is determined under the Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Base Percentage A.
</I>
	&#147;Base
	Percentage A&#148; means the percentage determined in accordance with Section III.B.1.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Base Percentage B.
</I>
	&#147;Base Percentage B&#148; means the percentage determined in accordance with Section III.B.2.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Board.
</I>
	&#147;Board&#148; means the Board of Directors of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Code.
</I>
	&#147;Code&#148; means the Internal
	Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (including, when the context requires, all regulations, interpretations and rulings issued thereunder).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Committee.
</I>
	&#147;Committee&#148; means the Compensation Committee of the Board or such other committee appointed by the
	Board to exercise the powers and perform the duties assigned to the Compensation Committee under this Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Company.
</I>
	&#147;Company&#148; means United Continental Holdings, Inc.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Disability.
</I>
	&#147;Disability&#148; means the
	Qualified Employee has been determined to be disabled under the Employer&#146;s long-term disability plan in which such Qualified Employee participates, under the union-sponsored long-term disability plan in which such Qualified Employee
	participates, or by the Company pursuant to Plan Rules.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Domestic Employee.
</I>
	&#147;Domestic Employee&#148; means any
	regular full-time or regular part-time U.S. employee of an Employer, and also includes (1)&nbsp;any internationally based flight attendant covered by the collective bargaining agreement between United Air Lines, Inc. and the Association of Flight
	Attendants, (2)&nbsp;any employee of Continental Micronesia, Inc. on the U.S. payroll, and (3)&nbsp;any employee designated by the Employer as an expatriate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Employer.
</I>
	&#147;Employer&#148; means United Airlines, Inc., Continental Airlines, Inc., Continental Micronesia, Inc.,
	Mileage Plus, Inc., and any other Affiliate which is designated by the Company from time to time as participating in the Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	ERISA.
</I>
	&#147;ERISA&#148; means the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as from time to time amended,
	including any related regulations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	UCH&nbsp;PSP
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">
	2
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016&nbsp;(FINAL)
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<A NAME="eolPage135"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Furlough.
</I>
	&#147;Furlough&#148; means a Qualified Employee&#146;s
	termination of employment with the Employer in connection with which such Qualified Employee has reemployment rights, or, in the case of a Qualified Employee who is in a class or craft of employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement with
	the Employer pursuant to which the Employer has agreed to provide such Qualified Employees with participation in a profit sharing bonus plan, such other employment action as may be defined as a &#147;furlough&#148; in the applicable collective
	bargaining agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	International Employee.
</I>
	&#147;International Employee&#148; means any regular full-time or
	regular part-time employee of an Employer whose regular work is in a location outside of the United States, but does not include (1)&nbsp;any internationally based flight attendant covered by the collective bargaining agreement between United Air
	Lines, Inc. and AFA, (2)&nbsp;any employee of Continental Micronesia, Inc. on the U.S. payroll, or (3)&nbsp;any employee designated by the Company as an expatriate. In addition, any full-time or regular part-time employee who is not classified by an
	Employer as a &#147;U.S. employee&#148; shall be considered an International Employee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Management and Administrative
	Employee Group.
</I>
	&#147;Management and Administrative Employee Group&#148; means those Domestic Employees of the Employer (i)&nbsp;who are classified by the Employer as management and administrative employees (on other than a temporary
	reclassification basis), (ii)&nbsp;whose employment is for an indefinite period, and (iii)&nbsp;who are employed in an Employer established job classification not covered by a collective bargaining agreement. In addition, the term &#147;Management
	and Administrative Employee Group includes any class or craft of U.S. employees who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement between an Employer and a union and who are not classified by the Employer as management and administrative
	employees but who nevertheless generally receive the same benefits as the Management and Administrative Employee Group.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Officer.
</I>
	&#147;Officer&#148; means (i)&nbsp;an &#147;officer&#148; of the Company as such term is defined in Rule
	16a-1(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (&#147;Rule 16a-1(f)&#148;), or (ii)&nbsp;a designated senior officer of the subsidiaries of the Company, including any officer of United Air Lines, Inc. or Continental Airlines, Inc.
	who is an &#147;officer&#148; of the Company under Rule 16a-1(f) or who reports directly to the Chairman or the CEO.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Participating Employee Group.
</I>
	Each employee group set forth in Appendix B is a Participating Employee Group. Expressly
	excluded from the definition are: (i)&nbsp;any class or craft of employees represented by a union but not covered by an agreement between an Employer and such union expressly providing for coverage under a Company-sponsored (or Employer-sponsored)
	profit sharing plan; and (ii)&nbsp;International Employees. In the event of any conflict between Appendix B and a collective bargaining agreement, the collective bargaining agreement shall govern.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Plan.
</I>
	&#147;Plan&#148; means the United Continental Holdings, Inc. Profit Sharing Plan as set forth herein. The Plan is
	an amendment and restatement of the UAL Corporation Success Sharing Program &#150; Profit Sharing Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="36%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
